ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze primary sources, especially those that are written in older dialects/styles of English. I also improved my writing skills. Finally, I was able to dive deeper into the American Revolution and learn about many interesting events/details concerning the event.
This course was great for looking at the American revolution through multiple perspectives.

I learned a lot about the causes of the American Revolution, and why it didn't happen in other British colonies like those in the Caribbean. The course also helped to dismantle several common narratives surrounding the Revolution.

I learned more about the inner workings of the American Revolution, specifically relating to its causes and the trajectory by which it evolved. Instead of the purely causal links often drawn by a survey course, I learned about the long form reasons for its existence. I also gained much insight into the Caribbean and what it was doing during the 1630s and beyond; specifically, what discourse did they have with Britain and why did they not revolt when America did. The two colonies analyzed the most were New York and Jamaica, however the course touched on all parts of the thirteen colonies and most of the Caribbean.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The readings were very boring and the prof often described them as poorly written and irrelevent

Strengths: Interesting readings, workload isn't too heavy, it's made very clear what students need to do to do well on the papers.

Weaknesses: It would be helpful if we had some guiding questions or something of that nature while doing the reading, so that we can gather some specific thoughts/insights to share during class

The material of the course was very interesting but I don't think we really needed to purchase the books that we were asked to buy: we only used them for 1-2 readings. Although the material in the 4 chapters that we read was interesting, it doesn't seem too essential to the course that we needed to buy them.
The course set up was very simple which I enjoyed. The class could be improved by the inclusion of powerpoints or study guides that help explain broader themes.

Strengths: The readings (generally) were quite good and interesting. Until the later half of the semester leading up to the final, they were pretty manageable. The final essay was fun to research and write.
Weaknesses: The discussions. At times they felt more like Q and A with the professor about the readings rather than a living discourse between the students. This will, of course, vary from class to class, and there were plenty of good discussions in ours, said phenomenon was just noticeable at times. Some of the other essay prompts also felt disjointed with the rest of the course and like they did not fit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes- it was very interesting and i enjoyed the seminar format
I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in American history (or history in general).

I would recommend this course to someone who is really interested in the American revolution and its precursors. This course is not built for someone without previous knowledge about the revolution and one should have significant knowledge to get something out of itl.
I would, especially for those looking for a somewhat different perspective on the origins of the United States.

I would recommend this to a student interested in history with some background in US history. You don't need to know a ton off-hand, but having a general idea of the evolution of the American Revolution is helpful. Everything you need to know will be gone over though. The course gives you a solid introduction to reading analytically and the professor presents good advice regarding your essays.
